adventure.title: Adventure
adventure.text: From diving in the Red Sea to desert safaris, explore Egypt beyond the ordinary.

facts.title: Fascinating Fact About Egypt
facts.fact1: Egypt is home to the only remaining Wonder of the Ancient World â€” the Great Pyramid of Giza.
facts.fact2: The Nile River is the longest river in the world, stretching over 6,650 km.
facts.fact3: Ancient Egyptians invented one of the earliest forms of writing: hieroglyphics.
facts.fact4: The Library of Alexandria was one of the largest and most significant libraries of the ancient world.
facts.fact5: Egypt is known as the 'Gift of the Nile' because the river made civilization possible in the desert.
facts.fact6: The ancient Egyptians were the first to invent toothpaste, using ingredients like crushed eggshells and pumice.
facts.fact7: The Sphinx of Giza is one of the largest and oldest statues in the world.
facts.fact8: Cleopatra VII was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.
facts.fact9: Egypt has more than 118 identified pyramids across the country.
facts.fact10: The ancient Egyptian calendar was one of the first solar calendars, with 365 days in a year.

destinations.title: Top Tourist Destinations
destinations.luxor_desc: Known as the worldâ€™s greatest open-air museum
destinations.cairo_desc: Capital city and home of the Pyramids of Giza
destinations.aswan_desc: Peaceful Nile-side city with ancient temples
destinations.alexandria_desc: Historic coastal city founded by Alexander the Great

luxor.name: Luxor
luxor.fullText: Luxor is often called the worldâ€™s greatest open-air museum, with a concentration of ancient monuments unmatched anywhere else. On the East Bank of the Nile, the awe-inspiring Karnak Temple complex and Luxor Temple stand as reminders of the cityâ€™s grandeur during the New Kingdom. Across the river, the West Bank houses the Valley of the Kings, where pharaohs such as Tutankhamun were buried, alongside the Valley of the Queens and the stunning Temple of Hatshepsut.

hurghada.name: Hurghada
hurghada.fullText: Hurghada is one of the Red Seaâ€™s most famous resorts, renowned for its crystal-clear waters, colorful coral reefs, and vibrant marine life. Itâ€™s a paradise for divers and snorkelers, with world-class diving spots such as Giftun Island and nearby wreck sites. The city also offers water sports, desert safaris, and luxurious resorts catering to every kind of traveler.

sharm-el-sheikh.name: Sharm El Sheikh
sharm-el-sheikh.fullText: Sharm El Sheikh is world-renowned for its diving spots, golden beaches, and luxury resorts. Ras Mohammed National Park, with its spectacular coral reefs, is a highlight for divers, while Naama Bay offers bustling nightlife, restaurants, and shopping. Visitors can also embark on desert adventures, camel rides, and Bedouin-style dinners under the stars.

aswan.name: Aswan
aswan.fullText: Aswan is a serene Nile-side city, rich in history and culture. It is home to the beautiful Philae Temple dedicated to the goddess Isis, the monumental Abu Simbel temples built by Ramses II, and the impressive High Dam, a modern engineering marvel. The Nubian villages nearby add vibrant culture, colorful homes, and warm hospitality to the Aswan experience.

alexandria.name: Alexandria
alexandria.fullText: Founded by Alexander the Great, Alexandria is Egyptâ€™s historic Mediterranean gem. It was once home to the legendary Lighthouse of Alexandria and the Great Library, and today it boasts the modern Bibliotheca Alexandrina, a hub of knowledge and culture. The Citadel of Qaitbay, built on the site of the ancient lighthouse, stands as a majestic coastal fortress.

cairo.name: Cairo
cairo.fullText: Cairo, Egyptâ€™s bustling capital, is a city of contrasts where ancient wonders meet vibrant modern life. It is home to the world-famous Pyramids of Giza and the Sphinx, as well as the Egyptian Museum, which houses treasures of Tutankhamun and countless artifacts from pharaonic times. Islamic Cairo offers centuries-old mosques and madrassas, while Coptic Cairo preserves the heritage of Egyptâ€™s Christian community.

climate.title: Egypt Climate & Weather
climate.intro: Egypt has a desert climate with hot summers and mild winters. Rain is rare except in Alexandria, where winter showers are common. Always bring sunscreen, hats, and light clothes for summer, and a light jacket for cooler evenings.

cairo.name: Cairo
cairo.climate: Hot and dry most of the year, cooler in winter evenings.

alexandria.name: Alexandria
alexandria.climate: Mediterranean climate with mild winters and occasional rain.

aswan.name: Aswan
aswan.climate: Extremely hot in summer, pleasantly warm in winter.

luxor.name: Luxor
luxor.climate: Hot desert climate with cool nights in winter.

sharm-el-sheikh.name: Sharm El Sheikh
sharm-el-sheikh.climate: Sunny all year, warm winters and very hot summers.

hurghada.name: Hurghada
hurghada.climate: Mild winters and hot, dry summers with cool breezes.

winter.title: Winter (Decâ€“Feb)
winter.text: Light jacket or sweater, evenings can be cool.

spring.title: Spring (Marâ€“May)
spring.text: Comfortable clothes, watch for occasional sandstorms.

summer.title: Summer (Junâ€“Aug)
summer.text: Very hot, wear light cotton clothes, hat, sunscreen.

qa.title: Frequently Asked Questions
qa.q1: Do I need a visa to visit Egypt?
qa.a1: Most visitors require a tourist visa. Many nationalities can apply online for an e-visa or get one upon arrival.
qa.q2: What is the best time to visit Egypt?
qa.a2: October to April is the most pleasant period with mild weather, perfect for sightseeing.
qa.a3: Yes, Egypt is generally safe for tourists, especially in main tourist areas, but always stay cautious.
qa.q4: What currency is used in Egypt?
qa.a4: The official currency is the Egyptian Pound (EGP).
qa.q5: Can I use credit cards in Egypt?
qa.a5: Yes, credit cards are widely accepted in hotels, restaurants, and shops in major cities.
qa.q6: What language is spoken in Egypt?
qa.a6: Arabic is the official language, but English is commonly spoken in tourist areas.
qa.q7: What should I wear in Egypt?
qa.a7: Light clothing for the day, modest outfits for religious sites, and warmer clothes for evenings in winter.
qa.q8: Can women travel alone in Egypt?
qa.a8: Yes, but it is advisable to dress modestly and stay in safe areas.
qa.q9: How should I get around in Egypt?
qa.a9: Taxis, ride-hailing apps, domestic flights, and trains are common transport options.
qa.q10: Is tap water safe to drink?
qa.a10: It is better to drink bottled or filtered water to avoid stomach issues.
qa.a11: Yes, it is highly recommended for medical and travel-related coverage.
qa.q12: Can I visit the Pyramids of Giza?
qa.a12: Yes, the Pyramids are open year-round and offer guided tours and camel rides.
qa.q13: What souvenirs should I buy from Egypt?
qa.a13: Popular items include papyrus art, perfumes, jewelry, spices, and handcrafts.
qa.q14: How hot does it get in summer?
qa.a14: Temperatures can exceed 40Â°C (104Â°F) in Upper Egypt and desert areas.
qa.a15: Rain is rare, mostly occurring in Alexandria and coastal cities during winter.
qa.q16: Are there dress codes for visiting mosques?
qa.a16: Yes, modest clothing is required: long pants, covered shoulders, and women should cover their hair.
qa.q17: Do I need vaccinations before visiting?
qa.a17: Routine vaccinations are recommended. Check with your doctor for travel-specific advice.
qa.a18: Photos are allowed in most places, but some museums and tombs require an extra ticket.
qa.a19: Tipping (baksheesh) is customary in Egypt, especially for small services.
qa.q20: What electrical plugs are used in Egypt?
qa.a20: Egypt uses Type C and Type F plugs with 220V supply.

culture.title: Egyptian Culture
culture.intro: Egyptian culture is a rich blend of ancient traditions and modern influences, reflecting thousands of years of history and civilization.
culture.clothingText: Traditional clothing varies across regions. In rural areas, galabeyas are common, while in cities, modern fashion blends with modest styles.
culture.traditionsText: Family and hospitality are central to Egyptian traditions. Respect for elders and strong community ties are deeply valued.
culture.festivalsText: Egypt celebrates many festivals, from Islamic and Christian holidays to ancient-inspired celebrations like Sham El-Nessim.
